execution.description: Algorithm to verify the signature on the token.
Identifies the recipients that the JWT is intended for.
A list of headers that must be understood by the server in order to accept the token as valid.
If nested signing or encryption is employed, it is recommended to set this to JWT; otherwise, omit this field.
Key to encrypt data (must contains EXACTLY 16 characters)

Identifies the expiration time on and after which the JWT must not be accepted for processing. The value must be a NumericDate:[9] either an integer or decimal, representing seconds past 1970-01-01 00:00:00Z.
Identifies the time at which the JWT was issued. The value must be a NumericDate.
Identifies principal that issued the JWT.
Case-sensitive unique identifier of the token even among different issuers.
A hint indicating which key the client used to generate the token signature.
Identifies the time on which the JWT will start to be accepted for processing. The value must be a NumericDate.
Identifies the subject of the JWT.
A certificate chain in RFC4945 format corresponding to the private key used to generate the token signature.
A URL where the server can retrieve a certificate chain corresponding to the private key used to generate the token signature.

plugins.description: Events sharing. These nodes try to optimize the performance of the application by sharing events between them to the maximum. Be careful, however, because if these nodes allow significant performance gains, their use can also create subtle errors, especially when the same event attribute can be modified by multiple nodes of the application
plugins.author: Hackeet

plugins.description: Transfers events only to a single descendant. Use this node to implement competitive situations between multiple resource consumers.
plugins.short_description: Transfers events only to a single descendant.
plugins.author: Hackeet

plugins.description:
Creates a Stripe Session object.
The 'items' parameter is a collection of JSON elements, each element being a JSON object representing an item to add to the session.
Ex:
[
{
'name':'Product #1',
'description':'My First Product',
'amount':1000,
'currency' : 'eur',
'quantity':1,
'image':'https://wwww.test.com/uneimage.jpg'
},
{
'name':'Product #2',
'description':'My Second Product',
'amount':1000,
'currency' : 'eur',
'quantity':1,
'image':'https://wwww.test.com/uneimage.jpg'
}
]

* The metadata parameter is a list of key-value pairs:
Ex:
[
{'key' : 'champ1', 'value':'value1' },
{'key' : 'champ2', 'value':'value2' },
{'key' : 'champ3', 'value':'value3' },
{'key' : 'champ4', 'value':'value4' }
]
plugins.author: Hackeet

execution.description: The URL to which Stripe should send customers when payment or setup is complete
The URL the customer will be directed to if they decide to cancel payment and return to your website
The mode of the Checkout Session (payment, setup, subscription)
A unique string to reference the Checkout Session.

plugins.description:
Starts commands as new processes and regularly monitors their execution status. When a process is complete, an event is sent on the Terminated port.
When starting a command, you can attach to it a user-defined id (attribute handler_id) or specify if it has to be respawned when terminated (set respawn to 1).
plugins.author: Hackeet

initialization.description: Delay (in ms) between two checks for process availability

channel.description:
Parameters :
command (Command to start)
handler_id (User-defined identifier to identify started process)
respawn (If different from 0, the process is started again on abnormal termination)

Parameters :
pid (Pid of the process to kill)

Parameters :
pid (Pid of the process to monitor)
handler_id (Handler id of the process)

Returned Attributes :
estimated_duration, handler_id, pid, respawn, status
